Transparency.findings: ExxonMobil mentions AI transparency principles aligned with NIST framework in their process safety documentation, but lacks detailed model cards or comprehensive transparency reports. Their proxy statement and ESG reporting include high-level statements about AI governance transparency without specific metrics or detailed disclosure frameworks. While they reference data transparency practices and workforce AI tool reporting, these appear to be general statements rather than concrete, detailed artifacts with specific transparency mechanisms.

Fairness & Bias Mitigation.justification: Score = 0 because none of the researched sources address Fairness & Bias Mitigation in any meaningful way.
Fairness & Bias Mitigation.findings: No public evidence found for this pillar.

Explainability.justification: Score = 0.5 because 2 source(s) (listed below) contain only high-level principle statements.

relevantSources.title: Enhancing Process Safety
relevantSources.summary: Mentions explainable AI in safety protocols.

Explainability.findings: ExxonMobil's digital technologies blog provides general explanations of their AI-driven methane detection systems without detailed explainability methods or tools. Their process safety documentation mentions explainable AI in safety protocols, but lacks specific techniques, interpretability frameworks, or explainability dashboards that would constitute concrete evidence. The sources provide high-level statements about AI explainability rather than detailed technical implementations.

Human Oversight & Accountability.justification: Score = 0.5 because 3 source(s) (listed below) contain only high-level principle statements.

relevantSources.title: Enhancing Process Safety
relevantSources.summary: Requires human validation of AI safety alerts.

Human Oversight & Accountability.findings: ExxonMobil's process safety documentation mentions human validation requirements for AI safety alerts, but doesn't detail specific oversight committees or appeal processes. Their proxy statement references board-level AI accountability frameworks without naming specific committees or providing charter details. The digital technologies blog describes human-AI collaboration in exploration activities, but these descriptions appear to be high-level statements rather than detailed workflows or accountability mechanisms.

Privacy & Security.justification: Score = 0.5 because 3 source(s) (listed below) contain only high-level principle statements.
Privacy & Security.findings: ExxonMobil's CareerConnect Data Privacy Notice mentions GDPR-compliant AI data protection, but lacks specific details about AI training data collection, consent mechanisms, or anonymization techniques. Their proxy statement references security protocols for AI systems without specifying encryption standards or data protection measures. The LinkedIn privacy policy disclosures appear to be general statements rather than AI-specific privacy practices with detailed data handling protocols.

Governance & Accountability.justification: Score = 0.5 because 3 source(s) (listed below) contain only high-level principle statements.
Governance & Accountability.findings: ExxonMobil's proxy statement mentions board-level AI governance structure without naming specific AI governance offices or providing organizational charts. Their process safety documentation references an operational integrity framework for AI without detailing specific governance mechanisms or responsible AI initiatives with budget allocations. The ESG report mentions ethics committee oversight but lacks specific information about AI governance team composition, reporting structures, or dedicated responsible AI resources.

Public Commitments & External Audits.justification: Score = 0.5 because 3 source(s) (listed below) contain only high-level principle statements.
Public Commitments & External Audits.findings: ExxonMobil's proxy statement mentions third-party AI audits without providing actual audit reports or certification details. Their ESG report references a public net-zero commitment that includes AI considerations, but lacks specific AI framework memberships or certifications. The advocacy report discusses trade association AI policy alignment without evidence of formal participation in AI ethics organizations like Partnership on AI or adherence to specific AI principles frameworks.

summary.overallFindings: ExxonMobil demonstrates a basic level of responsible AI transparency, explainability, oversight, privacy, governance, and public commitments, but all evidence is limited to high-level principle statements and lacks concrete, detailed documentation. There is no public evidence of fairness or bias mitigation practices. Across all pillars, the company does not provide detailed model cards, audit reports, or technical frameworks, indicating significant gaps in the maturity and public disclosure of its responsible AI practices. Overall, ExxonMobil's responsible AI disclosures are limited and do not meet the standards for leading practice.
